message: Week 9 Learning Outcomes identified: (1) Defining intelligence, (2) Four major theories of intelligence (Spearman, Cattell, Sternberg, Gardner), (3) Intelligence testing methods (Stanford-Binet, Wechsler, Raven's), (4) Gender and racial differences in IQ, (5) The Flynn Effect

Week 9 Key Theories Extracted: (1) Spearman's Two-Factor Theory (g + s factors), (2) Cattell's Fluid vs Crystallized Intelligence (gf-gc), (3) Sternberg's Triarchic Theory (3 types), (4) Gardner's Multiple Intelligences (8 types). Historical note: Binet-Simon test (1905) was first individual IQ test.

data.historical_milestone: Simon-Binet test 1905 - first individual IQ test

message: Week 9 Intelligence Testing Methods: (1) Stanford-Binet test (1905 origin, 5th edition 2003, Mean=100, SD=15, verbal/nonverbal scales based on gf-gc theory), (2) Wechsler Tests (most widely used globally: WPPSI-IV for 2.5-6 yrs, WISC-V for 6-16 yrs, WAIS-V for 16-90 yrs), (3) Raven's Progressive Matrices (non-verbal, culture-reduced). Historical: Army Alpha/Beta tests were first GROUP IQ tests (WWI, 1917-1919).

Week 9 Controversial Topics: (1) Gender differences: Males better at visuo-spatial tasks (mental rotation ~1 SD above females) and mechanical/quantitative reasoning; Females better at verbal tasks (synonym generation, verbal fluency ~0.5-1.2 SD above males) and some memory tasks. Most IQ tests constructed to show no overall gender difference. (2) Racial differences: Herrnstein & Murray (1994) Bell Curve reported 1 SD gap between Black (85) and White (100) IQ means in USA. APA task force concluded environmental/cultural factors, not genetics, explain differences. Three explanations: test bias, genetics (rejected - race is social construct), environment (consensus view).

gender_differences.note: Most IQ tests constructed for no overall difference

racial_differences.consensus: Environmental/cultural factors explain differences, not genetics

message: Week 9 Flynn Effect: IQ scores have increased ~3 points per decade across 30+ countries. Largest gains in FLUID intelligence (reasoning, pattern recognition like Raven's Matrices), not crystallized (vocabulary, facts). Observed since mid-20th century but slowing/reversing in some developed nations (Norway, Denmark, UK) since late 1990s. Explanations: better nutrition (prenatal/childhood brain growth), longer schooling, cognitive stimulation (TV, puzzles, video games, VR), smaller families (more parental attention), test familiarity.

Week 10 Learning Outcomes: (1) What is abnormality? (7 definitions), (2) Classification of mental disorders (DSM-5, ICD), (3) Anxiety disorders (7 types), (4) Obsessive-compulsive and related disorders (5 types), (5) Depressive and bipolar disorders (4 types), (6) Schizophrenia spectrum (5 types), (7) Personality disorders (10 types in 3 clusters). Historical: Kraepelin published first psychiatry textbook (1883), basis for DSM and ICD.

Week 10 Definitions of Abnormality: (1) Statistical deviation - rarity but includes gifted individuals, (2) Deviation from social norms - rule-breaking perspective, (3) Deviation from ideal mental health - varies across cultures, (4) Personal distress - subjective suffering (e.g., OCD), (5) Others' stress - interpersonal impact (e.g., narcissistic PD), (6) Maladaptiveness - impaired functioning (e.g., substance use), (7) Unexpected behavior - out of proportion responses (e.g., anxiety disorders).

data.key_insight: Multiple perspectives needed - no single definition sufficient

message: Week 10 Classification Systems: DSM-5 has 20 major categories. Example diagnostic criteria shown for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD): requires 5+ symptoms for 2+ weeks including depressed mood OR loss of interest/pleasure, plus symptoms like weight/appetite changes, sleep disturbance, psychomotor changes, fatigue, worthlessness/guilt, concentration problems, suicidal thoughts. Must cause significant distress/impairment.

criteria.required_symptom: depressed mood OR loss of interest

data.ICD: International Classification of Diseases - parallel system

message: Week 10 Anxiety Disorders (7 types): (1) Separation Anxiety Disorder - excessive fear of separation from attachment figures, (2) Selective Mutism - failure to speak in specific social situations, (3) Specific Phobia - intense fear of specific objects/situations (animals, heights, blood/injection), (4) Social Anxiety Disorder - persistent fear of social judgment, (5) Panic Disorder - recurrent unexpected panic attacks with persistent worry, (6) Agoraphobia - fear of situations where escape difficult, (7) Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) - chronic excessive worry for 6+ months about multiple life areas.

anxiety_disorders.name: Selective Mutism
anxiety_disorders.key_feature: failure to speak in specific situations

message: Week 10 OCD and Related Disorders (5 types): (1) OCD - obsessions (intrusive thoughts) and/or compulsions (repetitive behaviors like cleaning, checking, symmetry), (2) Body Dysmorphic Disorder - preoccupation with perceived appearance flaws not observable to others, repetitive mirror checking, (3) Hoarding Disorder - persistent difficulty discarding possessions, clutter congests living areas, (4) Trichotillomania - recurrent hair-pulling leading to hair loss, (5) Excoriation Disorder - recurrent skin-picking resulting in skin lesions.

Week 10 Depressive and Bipolar Disorders (4 types): (1) Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) - depressed mood/loss of interest for 2+ weeks with sleep, appetite, energy, concentration changes or suicidal thoughts, (2) Persistent Depressive Disorder - chronic low mood for 2+ years, less severe but more enduring than MDD, (3) Bipolar I - at least one manic episode (elevated/expansive/irritable mood with increased energy, marked impairment, may include psychosis/hospitalization), (4) Bipolar II - recurring hypomanic episodes (milder mania without severe impairment) plus major depressive episodes, no full manic episodes.

mood_disorders.name: MDD
mood_disorders.features: depressed mood, loss of interest, suicidal thoughts

mood_disorders.name: Persistent Depressive Disorder
mood_disorders.features: chronic low mood, less severe than MDD

message: Week 10 Schizophrenia Spectrum (5 types): (1) Schizophrenia - chronic disorder with psychotic symptoms (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech/behavior, negative symptoms) lasting 6+ months, significant functional decline. Types of delusions: persecutory, reference, grandiose, control, thought insertion/withdrawal/broadcasting, somatic, nihilistic. Speech pattern: clanging (rhyming nonsensically). (2) Schizophreniform Disorder - same symptoms as schizophrenia but 1-6 months duration. (3) Schizoaffective Disorder - psychotic symptoms PLUS mood episodes (depressive or manic). (4) Brief Psychotic Disorder - sudden onset, 1 day to <1 month, full return to baseline, often stress-triggered. (5) Delusional Disorder - one or more delusions for 1+ month with otherwise normal functioning. Types: erotomanic, persecutory, somatic, jealous.

Week 10 Personality Disorders - 10 types in 3 clusters: CLUSTER A (Odd/Eccentric): (1) Paranoid PD - believes others exploiting/harming them, unjustified doubts about loyalty, reluctant to confide (e.g., Joseph Stalin), (2) Schizoid PD - neither desires nor enjoys relationships, solitary activities, emotional coldness (e.g., Bill Gates), (3) Schizotypal PD - magical thinking, ideas of reference, odd beliefs/appearance/speech, unusual perceptual experiences (e.g., Van Gogh). CLUSTER B (Dramatic/Emotional/Erratic): (4) Antisocial PD - disregard for others' rights, deceitful, aggressive, no remorse (e.g., Ted Bundy), (5) Borderline PD - unstable mood/self-image/relationships, fear of abandonment, self-harm (e.g., Amy Winehouse, Marilyn Monroe), (6) Histrionic PD - attention-seeking, theatrical, shallow emotions, provocative (e.g., Madonna, Johnny Depp), (7) Narcissistic PD - grandiosity, needs admiration, lacks empathy, fragile self-esteem (e.g., Kanye West, Donald Trump, Steve Jobs).

Week 10 Personality Disorders - CLUSTER C (Anxious/Fearful): (8) Avoidant PD - extreme social inhibition, feelings of inadequacy, hypersensitive to criticism/rejection, avoids jobs with contact, very shy (e.g., Michael Jackson), (9) Dependent PD - excessive need to be cared for, submissive/clinging behavior, terror of separation, lets others take responsibility, fears being alone (e.g., Scott Disick), (10) Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder (OCPD) - rigid perfectionism, orderliness, control at expense of flexibility, preoccupied with rules/lists, workaholic, miserly, hoarding (e.g., Elon Musk). NOTE: OCPD is different from OCD.

Cluster_C_anxious_fearful.name: Dependent PD
Cluster_C_anxious_fearful.key: need to be cared for, submissive, separation terror

message: COMPLETED: Created comprehensive analysis document (weeks_9_10_content_analysis.md) containing: Week 9 (Intelligence) - 5 learning outcomes, 4 major theories, 3 testing methods, gender/racial differences analysis, Flynn Effect. Week 10 (Psychopathology) - 7 definitions of abnormality, DSM-5 with 20 categories, 31 specific disorders across 5 categories (7 anxiety, 5 OCD-related, 4 mood, 5 schizophrenia spectrum, 10 personality disorders in 3 clusters). Document includes detailed definitions, diagnostic criteria, examples, historical context, and notes for quiz generation. Ready for JSON conversion phase.

data.content_quality: comprehensive with examples, diagnostic criteria, historical context
